node.text: The fast-spreading #deltavariant is raising fresh health concerns even in places where Covid vaccination rates are high. Senior pharmaceuticals analyst Sam Fazeli is here to tell you what you need to know.

node.title: Your Biggest Delta Variant Questions Answered

node.text:
"Donald Trump upended the American presidency after stepping away from the company that made him rich and famous. Four years later, returning to his empire after losing the White House, what he finds may upend him," write Sophie Alexander and Max Abelson.

"Three quarters of Trump's net worth is tied up in urban real estate. And urban real estate has been hammered by Covid-19," Tim O'Brien tells @quicktake's Tim Stenovec.

The former president's net worth is down to $2.3 billion from $3 billion in 2016. The pandemic he promised would disappear is walloping his company, and the riot that got him impeached for a second time is wounding his brand.

Check out "Trump’s Ailing Empire" on bloomberg.com/graphics to see just how deep in peril he really is.

node.text:
👻 Snap Inc. is rolling out a new tool for its Snapchat app to feature popular videos, called Spotlight, and said it will pay out $1 million a day to creators of the top-performing posts. How good of a deal is that?

🤳🏻 "The more remarkable thing about Snap is that it wasn't offering these sort of incentives to people to create good content previously."

Alex Webb joined @quicktake's Tim Steno to explain why Snap decided to compensate viral creators.

#snapchat #influencer #app #creators #snap

node.title: Snapchat to Pay $1 Million a Day to Creators

node.text:
It’s been 20 months since a pair of fatal crashes forced regulators around the globe to ground the once top-selling jet. The FAA finally approved the Max to resume commercial flights today, which will allow Boeing to make money off the roughly 450 Max jets it has built but not yet delivered.

After the longest grounding of an aircraft in modern U.S. history, it’s reasonable to ask whether the plane is safe. Bloomberg Opinion columnists Chris Bryant and Brooke Sutherland teamed up to discuss the future of the Max, and whether or not they'd be willing to board one.

#Boeing #Boeing737 #737max #airplane #aircraft #airline #southwest #americanair #flight #pandemic #livestream #video #igtv #travel

node.title: Boeing’s 737 Max Is Back. Are You Willing to Board?

node.text:
Frank Barry didn’t ask a soul about Donald Trump or Joe Biden on his @looking4lincoln trip. For the two months he spent crossing the country along the Lincoln Highway by Winnebago, talking with Americans and hoping to reach San Francisco by Election Day, he never brought up the campaign. Sometimes he knew how people felt — occasionally they would say, though usually not. But it didn’t matter. He wasn’t running a focus group. He was trying to catch glimpses of a more enduring spirit, the kind that has transcended parties and generations, the kind that lives, as Lincoln said, in the better angels of our nature. And maybe those glimpses could help us see more of ourselves in each other, and in the land we share.

#lincolnhighway #travel #rv #roadtrip #winnebago #highway #ontheroad #interview #video

node.title: The End of the Lincoln Highway

May be an image of text that says 'Moderna is the hottest stock in pharma, thanks to its vaccine Moderna current market cap AstraZeneca Bristol-Myers Squibb Amgen Merck AbbVie $300B 200 100 2020 Source: Souce:Bloomberg 2021 BloombergOpinic'.

node.text:
📈 Moderna's value has soared past other drugmakers on the strength of a single product: its Covid-19 vaccine.

"As of now, the Covid jab is the company's only approved product, and its finite future sales depend on the very uncertain trajectory of the pandemic and booster shots," writes Max Nisen.

Single-product companies are usually targets rather than buyers when it comes to biotech. But Moderna is in the rare position of having the firepower to go on the hunt itself.

Moderna has plenty of deal capacity, with $12.2 billion in cash on hand and more coming in. Tap the link in our bio to read all about its acquisition strategy.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 09, 2021. May be an image of 3 people and text that says 'China'ssuccessinping-pong ping- China's success explainsits entire economic rise BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
To an outsider, China's system for minting ping pong stars looks deeply dysfunctional. Its success should tell us something about the country's economic rise, writes Tom Orlik. 

China has excelled at table tennis for decades, going back to the days of Mao Zedong. Grade-school children tapped for their potential repeat mechanical drills for hours each day, often with a coach firing hundreds of balls at them in quick succession. 

At the highest levels of the sport, politics intrudes. Yet despite rote training and corruption, China continues to mint golds in Ping-Pong. 

How? As with so much about the country’s economy, while the negatives are real, the positives outweigh them.

node.text:
🔥⛈A new report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change warns that the planet will warm by 1.5 degrees Celsius in the next two decades without drastic moves to eliminate greenhouse gas pollution.

Already, the past decade was most likely hotter than any period in the last 125,000 years.

Combustion and deforestation have raised carbon dioxide in the atmosphere higher than they’ve been in two million years.

Agriculture & fossil fuels have contributed to methane and nitrous oxide concentration higher than any point in at least 800,000 years.

🔗Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the IPCC’s landmark report.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 09, 2021. May be an image of 3 people and text that says 'Your basic level of happiness won't change much through life M BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Life events — losing one’s job, losing a limb, getting a divorce — tend to create only temporary changes in how happy people report they are. If you’re a person who usually rates their happiness as 5 on a scale of 1 to 7, then getting your arm amputated might make your typical response drop to a 2, but eventually it’ll probably rebound to a 4.

Why does happiness bounce back toward its previous level after major permanent life changes?

"One reason might be that a substantial component of happiness is dependent on deep-rooted personality traits — happy people are happy, unhappy people are unhappy, and life events simply have limited power to change this," writes Noah Smith.

"But an alternative explanation is that people’s frame of reference changes — if you spend long enough feeling sad, it might start to feel normal, and your responses to surveys might drift back toward what they had been before," he continues.

Tap the link in our bio to read Smith's column in full.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Here's how to tell when stocks are going to drop S&P500forecastedoperatgm 500 forecasted operating margin S&P 500 17% 5K 16 15 14 12 2009 Source: Source:Bloomberg 2021 2009 2021 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Want to know where the S&P 500 Index may be headed after reaching another record high? Take a look at profit margins.

Operating margin forecasts are a strong leading indicator of stock prices. Gina Martin Adams explains: "A decline in such outlooks preceded routs in the S&P 500 in 2011, 2015, 2018 and 2020. What’s concerning now is that analysts have stopped raising their forecasts, and if they begin to lower them, it's likely to lead to a dip in the broader market again."

What’s more, there’s not a lot of room for further improvement in margins, defined as earnings before interest and taxes divided by sales. Tap the link in our bio for an industry-by-industry look at forecasted profit margins.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 08, 2021. May be an image of ball and text that says 'Our future will be weirder than you think, sooner TATT OKYO2020 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🔮 150-year-old humans? New life forms on Earth? Intelligent visitors from outer space? It's all coming sooner than you think.

Take, for example, the possibility of intelligent life on other planets. Tyler Cowen writes: "Our ability to search for chemical and electro-magnetic extraterrestrial signals has been increasing steadily. Imagine a future where we learn we are not alone in the universe, even if alien life remains at a great distance. Some NASA scientists predict signs of alien life will be found by 2025."

That's not to mention the advances in AI, genomics, neural engineering and longevity research likely to come in the next few years. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how weird life on Earth could get.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Bloomberg Opinion on August 08, 2021 tagging @thebudgetnista. May be an image of 1 person, standing, outdoors and text that says 'Black homes are appraised at 23% less on average than similar homesin White neighborhoods BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🏡 In 2018, Tiffany Aliche (@thebudgetnista) and her husband purchased a home in foreclosure, gutted it and did a full renovation from the foundation to the hinges.

The house was fully paid off and they had been living in it for more than five months when they decided to pull out some equity from the place and invest it. But they'd first have to get their newly renovated home appraised.

As a precaution, Tiffany took down all of her family photos and ethnic artwork to minimize the chance of bias in the assessment process.

The appraisal came back at least $30,000 to $40,000 lower than it should have been. This was according to a different independent appraiser who reassessed the home using comparable homes in the surrounding area.
Tiffany is far from alone in her experience. The Brookings Institution found that “across all majority Black neighborhoods, owner-occupied homes are undervalued by $48,000 per home on average, amounting to $156 billion in cumulative losses.”

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about how Black homeowners can fight racial bias in appraisals.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 08, 2021. May be an image of indoor and text that says 'Not vaccinated? Here's you could kill someone's father. BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Art Krieg's father lived in a retirement home in central Pennsylvania, and got his Pfizer shots early in the year, as soon as they were available to people in his age group.

But he had an immune condition, called monoclonal gammopathy, which in addition to his advanced age made him vulnerable. He stayed home most of the time, but then in July, the perfect storm of events happened — a fall, then a trip to the emergency room during a local surge in Covid cases.

The hospital was so busy that it took five hours for his father to be seen. The Covid-19 diagnosis came a week later.

He doesn’t argue that his father caught the virus from an unvaccinated person — though he thinks the odds are about 20 to 1 that he did. The bigger issue is that the odds of his father being infected would have been much lower and the hospital less crowded if more people in the area had been vaccinated.

Tap the link in our bio to read Faye Flam's column about how devastating misinformation can be.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion in California. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'California will pay you to stay off the grid during a blackout BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
A confluence of factors has exposed the vulnerabilities of California's grid, mostly centered on this summer’s unusually widespread hot and dry conditions. Hydropower reservoirs are low. Neighboring states may send less electricity California’s way. Customers with air-conditioning are cranking it up.

Now Governor Gavin Newsom has declared a state of emergency to avert blackouts and is effectively calling up the next line of defense: backup generators.

His declaration creates a temporary program through October to encourage “large energy users” to reduce their demand by shifting to in-house generators. Commit to a minimum level of reduction during grid emergencies or warnings, and they will be paid $2 for each kilowatt-hour avoided. That is … a lot, writes Liam Denning. Industrial customers in California paid an average of 14.4 cents for each kilowatt-hour of power supplied to them in 2020. The state is now offering 14 times that to not supply them when necessary.

The chance to earn the occasional windfall is a powerful incentive. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#california #blackout #grid #energy #generator

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 07, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'BEWARE OFTICKS! Tick season could be bad this year. Here's what you need to know BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Lyme disease is a growing health threat, and climate change is only going to make it worse.

The number of cases reported to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in 2019 was up more than 50% from 2004, and a warming climate is expanding the areas and seasons in which ticks thrive. This year, weather conditions may result in a larger-than-average tick population and increased risk of exposure.

Sam Fazeli writes: "When a tick infected with the bacteria that causes Lyme disease “bites,” the overall risk of transmitting the bacteria is 1% to 2% and increases depending on the length of time the tick remains attached. If transmission does happen, the risk of developing Lyme disease is thought to be about 5%."

There was once an effective vaccine available, but it was taken off the market. In the end, demonization of the pharma industry and anti-vaccination falsehoods essentially took away a perfectly good vaccine. Now a new one is in development by Pfizer. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion in Venice, Italy. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Venice's Venice'scruise-shipbanisthe ship ban is the startofanewerafortourism of a new era tourism MSC ORCHESTRA BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Does Venice hold the key to saving cities from mass tourism? Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi’s decision to ban giant cruise ships from Venice’s lagoon took effect last weekend.

"It might seem like a no-brainer given the ballooning size and damage caused by floating hulks carrying thousands of people, but it’s one that carries real economic trade-offs after the pandemic. It should be just the start: The tourism industry that calls for regulation alongside longer-term reinvention," writes Lionel Laurent.

In Italy, tourism accounts for 6% of gross domestic product and Venice is one of the country’s crown jewels, attracting millions of tourists in the pre-pandemic years and effectively chaining the historical city’s 50,000 residents to the travel industry.

What Venice’s cruise-ship ban shows is the value of regulation, beyond curbing the urge to travel itself — which is as old as civilization. Tap the link in our bio to read Laurent's column in full.
